March 27, 2011: Fiction
THE JUNGLE, by Clive Cussler with Jack Du Brul. (Putnam, $27.95.) Juan
Cabrillo and the crew of the Oregon undertake rescue operations from
Afghanistan to Myanmar.
SING YOU HOME, by Jodi Picoult. (Atria, $28.) Picoult takes on the issue of gay
rights in this novel about a music therapist who desperately wants a child; CD of
songs included.
THE WISE MAN’S FEAR, by Patrick Rothfuss. (DAW, $29.95.) In this sequel to
“The Name of the Wind,” the magician Kvothe continues to narrate his fantastical
life story.
THE GIRL WHO KICKED THE HORNET’S NEST, by Stieg Larsson. (Knopf,
$27.95.) The third volume of the Millennium trilogy, about a Swedish hacker and a
journalist.
LOVE YOU MORE, by Lisa Gardner. (Bantam, $26.) Detective D. D. Warren must
solve the case of a dead husband, a battered wife and a missing child.
A DISCOVERY OF WITCHES, by Deborah Harkness. (Viking, $28.95.) The
recovery of a lost ancient manuscript in a library at Oxford sets a fantastical
underworld stirring.
MINDING FRANKIE, by Maeve Binchy. (Knopf, $26.95.) A motherless girl is cared
for by a Dublin community.
THE PARIS WIFE, by Paula McLain. (Ballantine, $25.) Ernest Hemingway’s first
wife, Hadley, narrates this novel set in Paris.
RIVER MARKED, by Patricia Briggs. (Ace, $26.95.) The shapeshifter Mercy
Thompson and her mate, the Alpha werewolf Adam, confront evil lurking in the
Columbia River.
SILENT MERCY, by Linda Fairstein. (Dutton, $26.95.) Alexandra Cooper, a
Manhattan assistant district attorney, is called when a woman’s decapitated body
is found burning on the steps of a Harlem church.
THE TIGER’S WIFE, by Tea Obreht. (Random House, $25.) In an unnamed
Balkan country, Natalia, a young doctor, investigates the mysterious
circumstances surrounding her beloved grandfather’s death.
TICK TOCK, by James Patterson and Michael Ledwidge. (Little, Brown, $27.99.)
The New York detective Michael Bennett enlists the help of a former colleague to
solve a rash of horrifying crimes that are throwing the city into chaos.
TREACHERY IN DEATH, by J. D. Robb. (Putnam, $26.95.) Eve Dallas and her
partner, Peabody, investigate a grocer’s murder.
March 27, 2011
Non-Fiction
THE SOCIAL ANIMAL, by David Brooks. (Random House, $27.) Brooks creates
two imaginary people, Harold and Erica, to illustrate his understanding of the
human mind, the wellsprings of action and the causes of success and failure.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner’s
story of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
MOONWALKING WITH EINSTEIN, by Joshua Foer. (Penguin Press, $26.95.) A
journalist who covered a mnemonics championship tries competing himself.
TOWNIE, by Andre Dubus III. (Norton, $25.95.) In this memoir, Dubus explores
his attachment to violence and his relationship with his famous father.
A SIMPLE GOVERNMENT, by Mike Huckabee. (Sentinel, $26.95.) The ex-
governor of Arkansas proposes 12 things he says Americans need from the
federal government.
DECISION POINTS, by George W. Bush. (Crown, $35.) The former president’s
memoir discusses his Christianity, the end of his drinking and his decisions on
9/11, Iraq and Katrina.
CLEOPATRA, by Stacy Schiff. (Little, Brown, $29.99.) A biography of the last
queen of ancient Egypt.
THE INFORMATION, by James Gleick. (Pantheon, $29.95.) Gleick argues that
information is “the blood and the fuel, the vital principle” of the world.
BLOOD, BONES, AND BUTTER, by Gabrielle Hamilton. (Random House, $26.) A
memoir by the chef and owner of the Manhattan restaurant Prune.
JESUS OF NAZARETH, by Joseph Ratzinger. (Ignatius Press, $24.95.) Pope
Benedict XVI challenges readers to grapple with the meaning of Jesus’ life.
BATTLE HYMN OF THE TIGER MOTHER, by Amy Chua. (Penguin Press,
$25.95.) A Chinese-American mother makes a case for strict and demanding
parenting.
KNOWN AND UNKNOWN, by Donald Rumsfeld. (Sentinel, $36.) The former
defense secretary’s memoir discusses his role in the invasion and occupation of
Iraq.
UNTIED, by Meredith Baxter. (Crown Archetype, $25.) The actress examines her
struggles with alcohol, relationships and breast cancer.
LIFE, by Keith Richards with James Fox. (Little, Brown, $29.99.) The Rolling
Stones guitarist’s autobiography is also a portrait of the era when rock ‘n’ roll came
of age.
